revisions.rev:
{{pp-move-indef}} {{Infobox athlete | name = Caster Semenya | image =20090819 Caster Semenya cropped.jpg | imagesize = 200px | caption = | nationality =[[South Africa]]n | sport = [[Running]] | event =[[800 metres]], [[1500 metres]] | club = | birth_date ={{Birth date and age|1991|1|7|df=yes}} | birth_place =[[Polokwane|Pietersburg]] (now Polokwane) | residence = | death_date = | death_place = | height = {{convert|1.70|m|ftin}} | weight ={{convert|64|kg|lb}} | pb= '''800m''': 1:55.45
'''1500m''': 4:08.01 | medaltemplates = {{MedalSport | Women's [[Athletics (sport)|athletics]]}} {{MedalCountry | {{RSA}} }} {{MedalCompetition|[[IAAF World Championships in Athletics|World Championships]]}} {{MedalGold|[[2009 World Championships in Athletics|2009 Berlin]]|[[2009 World Championships in Athletics â Women's 800 metres|800 m]]}} {{MedalSilver|[[2011 World Championships in Athletics|2011 Daegu]]|[[2011 World Championships in Athletics â Women's 800 metres|800 m]]}} }} '''Mokgadi Caster Semenya''' (born 7 January 1991) is a [[South Africa]]n [[middle-distance runner]] and world champion.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8215112.stm|title= Birth certificate backs SA gender |date=21 August 2009|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=21 August 2009}} Semenya won gold in the women's [[800 metres]] at the [[2009 World Championships in Athletics|2009 World Championships]] with a [[800 metres#Women's Seasons Best (Outdoor)|time of 1:55.45]] in the final. Following her victory at the 2009 World Championships, it was announced that she had been subjected to "gender testing".{{cite news |url= http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/more_sport/athletics/article6802314.ece |title=Caster Semenya faces sex test before she can claim victory |publisher=''[[The Times]]''|date=19 August 2009 |accessdate=20 August 2009 | location=London | first=Owen | last=Slot}} She was withdrawn from international competition until 6 July 2010 when the IAAF cleared her to return to competition.{{cite news|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hMudI8ByYmbiNVB4ofKjep_IT_kQD9GPJLSO0|title=Semenya cleared to return to track immediately|accessdate=6 July 2010|agency=Associated Press|date=6 July 2010}}{{dead link|date=September 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/sport/2010/jul/06/caster-semenya-iaaf-clearance|title=Caster Semenya may return to track this month after IAAF clearance|accessdate=6 July 2010|publisher=The Guardian|date=6 July 2010 | location=London | first=Anna | last=Kessel}} In 2010, the British magazine ''[[New Statesman]]'' included Semenya in a list of "50 People That Matter 2010".{{cite web|title=Caster Semenya â 50 people that matter 2010|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/2010/09/intersex-symbol-caster-semenya|accessdate=15 October 2010}} Semenya returned to the [[2011 World Championships in Athletics|2011 World Championships]] where she achieved the silver medal in the 800 metres. ==Early life and education== Semenya was born in Ga-Masehlong, a village in [[South Africa]] near [[Polokwane|Pietersburg]] (now Polokwane), and grew up in the village of Fairlie, "deep in South Africa's northern [[Limpopo]] province."{{cite web|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1208227/She-wouldnt-wear-dresses-sounds-like-man-phone-Caster-Semenyas-father-sex-riddle-daughter.html |title= 'she wouldn't wear dresses and sounds like a man on the phone': Caster Semenya's father on his sex-riddle daughter |date=23 August 2009|publisher=''[[Daily Mail]]'' |accessdate=27 August 2009}}She has three sisters and a brother, and is said to have been a [[tomboy]] as a child.{{cite web|url=http://www.universalsports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=23000&ATCLID=204778766|title=Caster Semenya's present and future|last=Abrahamson|first=Alan|date=20 August 2009|publisher=[[Universal Sports]]|accessdate=30 August 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Semenya attended Nthema Secondary School and now attends the [[University of Pretoria]] as a [[sports science]] student.[http://www.wistv.com/Global/story.asp?S=10963679 SAfrican in gender flap gets gold for 800 win]{{dead link|date=September 2011}} 22 August 2009, By RYAN LUCAS, Associated Press Writer She began running as training for [[association football|soccer]].{{cite web|url= http://www.thetimes.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=1057364 |title=Hero Casterâs road to gold|last=Prince |first=Chandre|date=29 August 2009|publisher=The Times|accessdate=30 August 2009}}{{dead link|date=September 2011}} ==Career== ===2008=== In July Semenya participated in the [[2008 World Junior Championships in Athletics|2008 World Junior Championships]], and won the gold in the 800 m at the [[2008 Commonwealth Youth Games]] with a time of 2:04.23.{{cite web|url= http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=6&click_id=4&art_id=nw20081016164120337C414633 |title= Young SA team strikes gold|date=16 October 2008|publisher=[[Independent Online (South Africa)|Independent Online]]|accessdate=21 August 2009}} ===2009=== In the [[2009 African Junior Athletics Championships|African Junior Championships]] Semenya won both the 800 m and 1500 m races with the times of 1:56.72 and 4:08.01 respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.africanathletics.org/?p=245|title=Nigerian Ogoegbunam completes a hat trick at Africa Junior Championships|last=Ouma|first=Mark |date=2 August 2009|publisher=AfricanAthletics.org|accessdate=21 August 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.iaaf.org/news/kind=100/newsid=52412.html|title=South African teen Semenya stuns with 1:56.72 800m World lead in Bambous â African junior champs, Day 2|last=Ouma |first=Mark |date=31 July 2009|publisher=[[IAAF]]|accessdate=21 August 2009}} With that race she improved her 800 m personal best by seven seconds in less than nine months, including four seconds in that race alone. The 800 m time was the world leading time in 2009 at that date.{{cite web |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/tomfordyce/2009/08/semenya_left_stranded_by_storm.html |title= Semenya left stranded by storm |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |author=Tom Fordyce |date=19 August 2009|accessdate=19 August 2009}} It was also a national record and a championship record. Semenya simultaneously beat the Senior and Junior South African records held by [[Zelda Pretorius]] at 1:58.85, and [[Zola Budd]] at 2:00.90, respectively.[http://www.iaaf.org/news/kind=100/newsid=52412.html South African teen Semenya stuns with 1:56.72 800m World lead in Bambous â African junior champs, Day 2] IAAF, 31 July 2009 The [[International Association of Athletics Federations]] (IAAF) says it was "obliged to investigate" after she made improvements of 25 seconds at 1500 m and eight seconds at 800 m â "the sort of dramatic breakthroughs that usually arouse suspicion of [[Use of performance-enhancing drugs in sport|drug use]]."[http://www.guardian.co.uk/sport/2009/aug/23/caster-semenya-athletics-gender Caster Semenya row: 'Who are white people to question the makeup of an African girl? It is racism': The decision to subject the gold medal-winning athlete Caster Semenya to sex tests over claims Caster is a man has provoked outrage in her village and throughout South Africa] David Smith, ''The Observer'', 23 August 2009 The IAAF also asked Semenya to undergo a [[gender test]] after the win.The IAAF ceased compulsory tests in 1992 but retains the right to test athletes. [http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn17663-scant-support-for-sex-test-on-champion-athlete.html Scant support for sex test on champion athlete] ''New Scientist'' [[Gender verification in sports|Gender verification]] was dropped from Olympic sports in 1999 as the issue was delicate and scientifically complicated. The verification involves "an [[endocrinologist]], a [[gynaecologist]], an [[internal medicine]] expert, an expert on gender and a psychologist" and takes several weeks. This is not the first time the IAAF has asked for gender verification although generally the athletes maintain their privacy. [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/more_sport/athletics/article6802314.ece "Caster Semenya faces sex test before she can claim victory"] ''The Times'', 19 August 2009 News that the IAAF requested the test broke three hours before the 2009 World Championships 800 m final. IAAF president [[Lamine Diack]] stated, "There was a leak of confidentiality at some point and this led to some insensitive reactions."{{cite news |url= http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/athletics/6078171/World-Athletics-Caster-Semenya-tests-show-high-testosterone-levels.html| title=World Athletics: Caster Semenya tests 'show high testosterone levels' | last=Hart| first=Simon |date=24 August 2009 |publisher=The Times |accessdate=30 August 2009 | location=London}} In August Semenya won gold in the [[2009 World Championships in Athletics â Women's 800 metres|800 metres]] at the [[2009 World Championships in Athletics|World Championships]] with a time of 1:55.45 in the final, again setting the fastest time of the year.{{cite web |url=http://berlin.iaaf.org/documents/pdf/3658/AT-800-W-f--1--.RS1.pdf |title=800 Metres Women Final Results |date=19 August 2009 |accessdate=20 August 2009}} ===Gender test=== Following her victory at the world championships, questions were raised about her gender.[http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SPORT/08/19/athletics.worlds.berlin.semenya/index.html Women's world champion Semenya faces gender test] CNN, 20 August 2009{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/athletics/8210471.stm|title= Semenya told to take gender test |publisher=BBC Sport|date=19 August 2009|accessdate=19 August 2009}} The IAAF's handling of the case spurred many negative reactions. A number of athletes, including retired sprinter [[Michael Johnson (athlete)|Michael Johnson]], criticized the organization for its response to the incident.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/athletics/8212078.stm| title=Semenya dismissive of gender row |publisher=BBC Sport|date=20 August 2009|accessdate=20 August 2009}}{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8212835.stm| title=South African unite behind gender row athlete |publisher=BBC News|date=20 August 2009|accessdate=20 August 2009}} Prominent South African civic leaders, commentators, politicians, and activists characterized the controversy as [[Racism|racist]], as well as an affront to Semenya's privacy and human rights.{{cite web|url= http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-africa-runner26-2009aug26,0,4216318.story| title=Caster Semenya, South African runner subjected to gender test, gets tumultuous welcome home|first=Robyn|last=Dixon|date=26 August 2009|publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|accessdate=29 August 2009}}{{cite news |url= http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/southafrica/6073980/Gender-row-over-Caster-Semenya-makes-athlete-into-a-South-African-cause-celebre.html |title= Gender row over Caster Semenya makes athlete into a South African cause celebre |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|date=23 August 2009 |accessdate=27 August 2009 | location=London | first1=Patrick | last1=Sawer | first2=Sebastian | last2=Berger}} The IAAF said it only made the test public after it had already been reported in the media, denying charges of racism and expressing regret about "the allegations being made about the reasons for which these tests are being conducted."[http://www.thetimes.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=1053584 SA to take up Semenya case with UN]{{dead link|date=September 2011}} ''The Times SA'', 21 August 2009 The federation also explained that the motivation for the test was not suspected cheating but a desire to determine whether she had a "rare medical condition" giving her an unfair competitive advantage.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8211319.stm|title=SA fury over athlete gender test |publisher=BBC Sport|date=20 August 2009|accessdate=20 August 2009}} The president of the IAAF stated that the case could have been handled with more sensitivity.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/athletics/8219937.stm| title=New twist in Semenya gender saga|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=25 August 2009|accessdate=29 August 2009}} In an interview with South African magazine ''[[YOU]]'' Semenya stated, "God made me the way I am and I accept myself." She also took part in a [[makeover]] with the magazine.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8243553.stm| title=Makeover for SA gender-row runner|publisher=BBC News|date=8 September 2009|accessdate=8 September 2009}} On 7 September 2009, Wilfred Daniels, Semenya's coach with Athletics South Africa (ASA), resigned because he felt that ASA "did not advise Ms. Semenya properly". He apologized for personally having failed to protect her.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8242060.stm| title=S. Africa gender row coach resigns|publisher=BBC News|date=7 September 2009|accessdate=27 September 2009}} Athletics South Africa President Leonard Chuene admitted on 19 September 2009 to having subjected Semenya to gender tests. He had previously lied to Semenya about the purpose of the tests and to others about having performed the tests. He ignored a request from ASA team doctor Harold Adams to withdraw Semenya from the world championships over concerns about the need to keep her medical records confidential.{{cite news|author=Serena Chaudhry| url= http://www.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idUSTRE58I0N320090919| title=South Africa athletics chief admits lying about Semenya tests|publisher=Reuters|date=19 September 2009|accessdate=27 September 2009}} On the recommendation of South Africa's Minister for Sport and Recreation, [[Makhenkesi Stofile]], Semenya retained the legal firm [[Dewey & LeBoeuf]] who are acting [[Pro bono publico|pro bono]] "to make certain that her civil and legal rights and dignity as a person are fully protected."[http://www.legalweek.com/legal-week/news/1534157/dewey-takes-semenya-iaaf-dispute Dewey takes up Semenya case in IAAF dispute] â Legalweek Magazine[http://timesonline.typepad.com/law/2009/09/dewey-leboeuf-to-advise-caster-semenya.html Dewey & LeBoeuf to advise Caster Semenya]{{dead link|date=September 2011}} â [[Times Online]][http://www.deweyleboeuf.com/en/Firm/MediaCenter/PressReleases/2009/09/DeweyLeBoeufRetainedtoProtectRightsofSouthAfricanRunnerCasterSemenya.aspx Dewey & LeBoeuf Retained to Protect Rights of South African Runner Caster Semenya] â press release from [[Dewey & LeBoeuf]]. Following the furore over her gender, Semenya received great support within South Africa, to the extent of being called a ''[[cause celebre]]''. In November 2009 South Africa's sports ministry issued a statement that Semenya had reached an agreement with the IAAF to keep her medal and the prize money.Jere Longman [http://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/20/sports/20runner.html "South African Runnerâs Sex-Verification Result Wonât Be Public"] ''New York Times'', 19 November 2009 The ministry did not say if she would be allowed to compete as a woman but they did note that the IAAF's threshold for when a female is considered ineligible to compete as a woman is unclear. In December 2009 [[Track and Field News]] voted Semenya the Number One Women's 800 metre runner of the year.Track and Field News, 22 December 2009 Vol 8 Number 59 ===2010=== [[File:Caster Semenya 2010 Memorial Van Damme.jpg|thumb|Semenya on the [[2010 Diamond League]] circuit]] In March 2010 she was denied the opportunity to compete in the local Yellow Pages Series V Track and Field event in [[Stellenbosch]], South Africa, because the IAAF had yet to release its findings from her gender test.{{cite web|url=http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/36083164/|title=Semenya announces return to competitive running|accessdate=30 March 2010|publisher=NBC Sports}}{{dead link|date=July 2010}} On 6 July, the IAAF cleared Semenya to return to international competition. The results of the gender tests, however, will not be released for privacy reasons. She returned to competition nine days later winning two minor races in [[Finland]].Yahoo News, July 18, 2010: [http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100718/ap_on_sp_ot/ath_semenya_comeback Semenya easily wins again in Finland]{{dead link|date=September 2011}} On August 22, 2010, running on the [[Olympic Stadium (Berlin)|same track]] as her World Championship victory, Semenya started slowly but finished strongly, dipping under 2:00 for the first time since the controversy, while winning the [[Internationales Stadionfest|ISTAF]] meet in Berlin.[http://www.universalsports.com/news/article/newsid=489615.html#rudisha+breaks+800m+wr+semenya+wins AP article]{{dead link|date=September 2011}} Not being on full form, she did not enter the [[2010 World Junior Championships in Athletics|World Junior Championships]] or the [[2010 African Championships in Athletics|African Championships]], both held in July 2010, and opted to target the [[2010 Commonwealth Games|Commonwealth Games]] to be held in October 2010.CBC, July 21, 2010: [http://www.cbc.ca/sports/amateur/story/2010/07/21/sp-semenya-commonwealth-games.html Semenya has eyes on Commonwealth Games] She improved her season's best to 1:58.16 at the [[Notturna di Milano]] meeting in early September and returned to South Africa to prepare for the Commonwealth Games.Sampaolo, Diego (2010-09-10). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/kind=100/newsid=58306.html Howe, Semenya, and Yenew highlight in Milan]. [[IAAF]]. Retrieved on 2010-09-10. Eventually, she was forced to skip the games due to injury.The Hindu, September 29, 2010: [http://www.thehindu.com/sport/athletics/article802398.ece Injured Semenya pulls out of Commonwealth Games] In September, the British magazine ''[[New Statesman]]'' included Semenya in its annual list of "50 People That Matter" for unintentionally instigating "an international and often ill-tempered debate on gender politics, feminism and race, becoming an inspiration to gender campaigners around the world." ==See also== * [[Gender verification in sports]] ==Notes== {{Refbegin}} {{Refend}} ==References== [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ffW5zeuPcds Part 2] YouTube * [http://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/22/sports/22runner.html "Where's the Rulebook for Sex Verification?"], New York Times, 21 August 2009 (Retrieved 31 January 2010) {{commons category}} {{Footer World Champions 800 m Women}} {{Footer WBYP 800m Women}} {{Persondata | NAME = Semenya, Caster | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = |
